description: b-Net income and after net income $ 151,000, or 5 cents a share, which included loss of $ 32,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $ 183,000, or 6 cents a share, on disposal of discontinued operations, in the quarter; the year included net income of $ 338,000, or 11 cents a share, from discontinued operations and a gain of $ 1,405,000, or 45 cents a share, on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Promus Companies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary losses of $ 527,000 and $ 2,215,000, in the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from the early extinguishment of debt, which were partially offset by gains of $ 211,000 and $ 890,000, in the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from net income tax benefits.c-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 5,558,000, in both the quarter and 6 months, from the early extinguishment of debt, which was partially offset by a gain of $ 4,353,000 on the forgiveness of joint venture debt and a gain of $ 458,000 from a net income tax benefit, in both periods.

title: Horacio Gutierrez Cancels
description: Because of a back injury, the pianist Horacio Gutierrez has canceled his appearances with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. Replacing him as soloist in the Mozart Piano Concerto No. 23 is to be Seung-Un Ha, making her Mostly Mozart debut. The remainder of the program remains unchanged and includes Haydn's Symphony No. 93 and Violin Concerto No. 1, with Gil Shaham, soloist, and Mozart's Symphony No. 36. George Cleve is to conduct. Information: (212) 721-6500.

title: Review/Theater; Singing, Dancing, a Bark or Two
description: No sooner does 9-year-old Kathryn Zaremba sing her first note in "Annie Warbucks," the long-labored-over musical that opened at the Variety Arts Theater last night, than the audience erupts into relieved, gratified chuckles. Ms. Zaremba, who plays the show's titular heroine, is very small, even for a 9-year-old, but her voice, which is pitched somewhere between a bugle and a gym teacher's whistle, is enormous. Never mind that her diction sometimes suggests that her cheeks have been stuffed with M&M's. The kid can belt, and she seems as un-self-conscious as a kitten.

title: Thorn Apple Valley Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for 12wks to May 28
Serbs Make a Gesture at Sarajevo, Then Dig In Heels
description: A melancholy smile spread across the face of a sodden Bosnian soldier standing in a forest clearing on Mount Igman today.

title: Velcro Industries NV (NSC) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflected an extraordinary nonrecurring charge of $ 868,000 in the quarter and 9 months.

title: Running Up the Track In the Viewing Race
description: When the Olympics are out of session, we Americans dine on a sparse diet of televised track and field and other summer events (save gymnastics, which we get in mass quantities). We want our Jackie Joyner-Kersees and Mike Powells for our quadrennial gorge every four years, then we slouch toward abstention.

title: NovaCare Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included nonrecurring charge of $ 5.7 million for restructuring expenses.c-Included nonrecurring charge of $ 4.7 million for merger and other related expenses.Year-ago periods were reclassified.

title: Autostock Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Candadian dollars.

title: Budget Cutters Discover Easy Target in Medicare
description: As one of the largest and fastest-growing Federal programs and one bearing the dreaded "entitlement" label at that, Medicare, which covers health care for the elderly, presented budget cutters with a plump target. And not surprisingly it took the biggest single hit, apart from the military, as Congress and the President wrapped up the new five-year economic plan last week.

title: Judge Restricting Nixon's Tapes
description: A Federal judge today barred the National Archives from releasing more of Richard M. Nixon's White House tapes until all personal conversations are separated and returned to the former President.

title: The Myth of Successful Aging
description: I spent a little more than a year among a group of people who were brought together by age and illness in a nursing home in western Massachusetts. This is an excerpt from my forthcoming book about them, "Old Friends." I set out to contemplate the problem of old age, and ended up interested not in a problem but in the lives of a few elderly people. Like every other situation, this one had its ordinary citizens and its heroes.

title: Job-Seekers Are Victims Of Ad Hoax
description: Two bogus ads, including one that encouraged people with criminal records to apply to a Manhattan judge for work as security guards, produced a deluge of job requests at the judge's offices on Sunday and yesterday.

title: Review/Music; Classic Improvisation (As in Quick Thinking)
description: The final concert of the 53d season of the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival, this evening, was enjoyable and at times sensational on its own terms. Still, it could only be anticlimactic after the bizarre and wonderful events of the night before.

title: Always There With an Assist
description: Adam Graves had bunk beds as a child. He didn't need them for sleepovers, he needed them for the constant stream of little boys who shared his room. There was always, it seemed, another child who needed a family, another child who needed a home.

title: Liftoff Nears for Lightweight Rocket
description: A REVOLUTIONARY kind of rocket ship is ready to rise from the launching pad for the first time, lifting some of the gloom that has enveloped aerospace experts recently as the nation's two main space vehicles were grounded by a series of tiny mishaps and one catastrophic failure.

title: Part of Immigrant Nightmare Goes on the Block
description: For Sale: Rusting 150-foot freighter. Name: Golden Venture. Last Voyage: To New York City from Southeast Asia, with 300 illegal immigrants from China aboard. Price: $17,500 or best bid. Prospects for future trips: Uncertain.

title: Reggie Lewis Passed Celtics' Treadmill Test in April
description: Reggie Lewis showed no signs of an abnormal heart when he underwent a stress test on a treadmill three days before he collapsed during a playoff game on April 29, the Celtics' physician said today.

title: Unigene Laboratories (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Unigene said that total revenues for both years consisted almost entirely of interest income.

title: Hampton's Request: Try Guessing What
description: Giants running back Rodney Hampton isn't mad -- yet. But the Pro Bowl player is just a little bothered by the fact the Giants haven't renegotiated his contract.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11 EUROPE CONFRONTS IMMIGRATION

title: Sleeping Face Down Seems to Put Babies At Risk, Studies Say
description: SUDDEN infant death syndrome, which affects 1 of every 1,000 infants born in this country, and many more worldwide, has long baffled scientists and researchers. Recently, mounting evidence has indicated that babies who sleep face down are at greater risk than those who sleep on their backs or sides.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: W. R. GRACE & CO., Boca Raton, Fla., has received Federal approval to sell about 350,000 kidney dialysis devices despite an earlier order banning their import from overseas plants. The devices, plastic tubing that hooks up to dialysis machines, had been barred under a Food and Drug Administration import ban issued for products from Grace plants in Mexico and Ireland because of safety concerns. The devices will carry a warning label. EQUIFAX INC., Atlanta, said it had acquired Integratec Inc., a privately held provider of credit card processing services, for about $23 million.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES TO LAY OFF MORE PILOTS
description: American Airlines said yesterday that it planned to lay off about 400 pilots in the next six months, or about 50 more than it had previously announced. In June, American said it planned to lay off about 350 pilots starting on Aug. 31. The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, employed 119,000 workers at the beginning of the year, 10,000 of them pilots.

A Free-Form Film Maker Who Spares All Expense
description: Critics often praise a director's work as "personal." It's a pretty safe bet that the films and videos of George Kuchar are not quite what they have in mind when using the term.

title: JUDGE DELAYS RULING ON MACY EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT
description: Judge Burton R. Lifland of Federal Bankruptcy Court has put off ruling on an employment agreement between R. H. Macy & Company and Roger N. Farah, pending the outcome of a lawsuit between Mr. Farah and his present employer, Federated Department Stores Inc.

title: Facing the Price of a Home Computer
description: WITH varying degrees of enthusiasm, parents and children are preparing to begin a new school year. For many people this is the time to shop for a home computer and educational software.

title: Prehistoric Climate
description: Scientists excavating a disused gravel quarry in Oxfordshire, England, have uncovered a giant graveyard of prehistoric mammoths and other animals. The remains, rare in their diversity and superb state of preservation, hold clues to the region's climate 220,000 years ago.

title: Moon's Thin Atmosphere Extends 5,000 Miles
description: ALTHOUGH scientists demonstrated earlier this century that the Moon has a thin atmosphere, its extent was a matter of speculation until two researchers at Boston University developed images of the sodium gas enveloping the Moon.

title: Continental Airlines Switches Agencies
description: Continental Airlines yesterday dismissed Wells Rich Greene BDDP, its agency since March 1990, and moved its estimated $40 million United States account, without a review, to the Richards Group in Dallas.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD Powell's Streak Intact The long jump world-record holder, Mike Powell, leaped 27 feet 10 inches yesterday in the last round at the Malmo Invitational Grand Prix track and field meet in Sweden. It was Powell's 22d straight victory since the Barcelona Olympics last summer. Earlier this summer, Powell won the United States championship with a mark of 28-1 1/2. Powell failed to jump 8 meters, or 26-3, in the first two rounds yesterday, but gradually produced longer and longer jumps, despite a drizzle. "In a way I miss Carl Lewis. I'm a man looking for challenges, which he gives me," Powell was quoted as saying by the Swedish news agency TT. Lewis won the Olympic long jump. Powell's countrymen, Dennis Mitchell and Kevin Braunskill, won the 100- and 200-meter races. Mitchell, an Olympic bronze medalist last year, was coming off an injury. He was clocked at 10.22 seconds in his only tuneup for the world track and field championships in Stuttgart, Germany, which begin Saturday. Braunskill's time was 20.61 seconds. (AP)

title: Chess
description: A selection of the world's top young women in chess defeated a group of senior men in a match in late June in Vienna. They thus got revenge for their defeat in the first match of this kind last year, which took place on Aruba in the Caribbean.

title: After Senate Loss, Abrams Tries to Stay in the Arena
description: By his own admission, Attorney General Robert Abrams lost last year's campaign for United States Senate because he committed the unpardonable political sin of letting his opponent, Alfonse M. D'Amato, define him.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY TURNING TO CONCRETE TO COVER A RESERVOIR When investigators traced an outbreak of bacteria in New York City tap water to gulls at the Hillview reservoir in Yonkers, city officials said the problem was temporary because they had plans to cover the reservoir with a concrete deck topped with a reflecting pool. But supporting the reflecting pool will take lots of concrete, $177 million worth. A1.

title: British Fly to Bosnian Girl's Rescue
description: After worldwide publicity about her plight, a 5-year-old girl severely wounded by a Serbian artillery shell was evacuated today from Sarajevo by a British military aircraft and flown to Britain, where she was hospitalized in critical condition.

title: Holidays Brought to Life On a Neighbor's Lawn
description: HOLIDAYS are a time for Richard Pond to get to work.

title: Colleges Spend Faster Than Parents Can Pay; It Can't Continue
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: CIRCLE K CORP., Phoenix, the convenience-store chain, named Mitch Telson, the executive vice president for operations, to be chief operating officer. He succeeds John F. Antioco, acting chief operating officer and president, who last week was given the additional post of chief executive. In addition, Tom Galligan was named chief financial officer. DIONEX CORP., Sunnyvale, Calif., appointed Barbara J. Posch vice president for finance and chief financial officer.

title: Energy Prices Rebound; Gold Also Regains Ground
description: Energy prices bounced back from their three-year lows yesterday, with unleaded gasoline futures leading the way after the shutdown of a fourth major refinery in two weeks.

title: EMC AGREES TO ACQUIRE EPOCH SYSTEMS
description: The EMC Corporation agreed yesterday to purchase Epoch Systems Inc. for 4.75 million shares. Under the agreement, the transaction price is subject to a limit that is below yesterday's closing price of $30.50 for EMC shares, according to an EMC spokesman. Based on that share price, however, the transaction would have a value of about $144.8 million.

description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 60,000 in both the quarter and 6 months.

title: What's Left From the Great Flood of '93
description: In its two-month rampage, the great Midwest flood of 1993 cut an awesome destructive swath. It took 50 lives, left almost 70,000 people homeless, inundated an area twice the size of New Jersey, caused an estimated $12 billion in property and agricultural damage and stirred anew a debate over the nation's flood-control system and its policies.

A Relatively Gentle American Campaign for Pizza Fixings Is Still Too Hard-Sell for British Tastes.
description: THE empire is long gone, Elton John has moved to Atlanta and tourists are trooping through Buckingham Palace. Still, it seems there'll always be an England, at least when it comes to the England that looks down its national nose at the creative efforts of American advertising agencies.

title: Sports of The Times; Building A Living Monument
description: THE call-in shows in Boston have moved along to something else. So it goes. There is a rumor that professional football is arriving in New England. The Yankees are in Fenway tonight for the start of a series, and a race is giving Red Sox fans reason to renew their happy hatred. So it goes.

title: Baghdad Journal; In Iraq, a 'One-Man Show' Acquires New Meaning
description: He comes in military uniform, naturally, or in a blue, brown, green or gray suit with matching breast pocket handkerchief. But you could also choose a picture of him sipping tea with gaily dressed Kurdish women amid snowy mountains, or talking to veiled Shiite Muslim women in the reeds of the southern marshes. You can have him praying, too.

title: The Heavy Hand of European Settlement
description: IT may be true, as some scientists have lately been saying, that the America encountered by the first European settlers was no primeval Eden, and that pre-Columbian Indians shaped, reshaped and sometimes degraded the landscape and ecology of the continent much as modern people do.

title: Subaru Lays Off 17.5% of Jobs in U.S.
description: Bowing to cost-cutting pressures and cutthroat competition in the United States automotive market, Subaru of America today eliminated 144 jobs, or 17.5 percent, from its American work force of 823 employees.

description: Mirza Smailbegovic is a 3 1/2-year-old boy who wants his mother. Often, after a mixture of potent drugs drips through a tube surgically implanted in his chest, he is overcome by nausea and asks the nurse, doctor or social worker at his bedside, "Where's my mama?"

ROCKWELL TO BUY WESTERN DIGITAL CHIP PLANT
description: The Rockwell International Corporation signed a letter of intent yesterday to purchase the Western Digital Corporation's chip manufacturing plant in Irvine, Calif., for $115 million. The sale will permit Western Digital to pay off most of its $137 million in bank debt. Shares of Western Digital rose 75 cents, to $5.75, as almost 1.1 million shares were traded. Mr. Blair said the plant had been producing about 1,800 wafer starts a week, well below its capacity of 3,000 weekly. Wafer starts represent the first step in turning a piece of silicon into a chip.

description: If this were the Giants of a few years ago, it might not be a matter of concern that the defensive line and the left side of the offensive line -- the side with the best players -- were being manned by understudies in the preseason.

description: Prices of pork bellies plunged yesterday for the sixth consecutive session as receding floodwaters in the Midwest encouraged farmers to dump hogs on the market.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: YACHT RACING Spain Edges U.S. The Spanish yacht, Galicia 93 Pescanova, beat Dennis Conner's round-the-world racer, Winston, to the finish line yesterday in the British Fastnet Race. By arriving in Plymouth, England at 12:57 A.M., New York time, Galicia was a half-hour ahead of Winston, and first to finish on elapsed time. The 605-mile competition from Cowes, England, drew 243 sailboats in a finale to the 1993 Champagne Mumm Admiral's Cup series. Galicia, skippered by Javier de la Gandara of Spain, is a sister ship to Winston. Both are 60-foot sailboats. Conner, who is competing elsewhere this week, was not on board Winston in the Fastnet.

title: Lam Research (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 307,000.

title: Company Earnings; PROCTER & GAMBLE CO. (N)
description: The Procter & Gamble Company yesterday reported record sales and operating earnings for the fiscal year ended June 30. Its chairman and chief executive, Edwin L. Artzt, described the results "as both our best year ever and one of our toughest."

title: Note Left by White House Aide: Accusation, Anger and Despair
description: In a note that mixed fury with despair, Vincent W. Foster Jr., the White House lawyer whose death last month has been ruled a suicide by the police, said he was not meant for "the spotlight of public life" in a city where "ruining people is considered sport."

title: Coleman Will Surrender And Plead No Contest
description: Vince Coleman, the Mets outfielder who faces a felony charge for igniting an explosive outside Dodger Stadium 17 days ago, will surrender to authorities here Wednesday.

title: Review/Television; The Burden of Yearning to Be Thin
description: The most affecting passages of "The Famine Within" are the first-person accounts of bouts with anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa. The young women who deliver them may not fully understand the roots of their compulsion to starve or stuff themselves, but their vivid memories leave no doubt of its power and the deep unhappiness from which it springs.

title: Callaway Golf Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1,658,000, or 10 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in March 1993.Sales represented net sales.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9 COMMANDOS MAY GO TO SOMALIA The U.S. is considering using commandos in Somalia to search for Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, who is suspected of being behind the killing of 4 American soldiers and 24 Pakistanis. A1 News analysis: The U.N. mission is now military enforcement. A2 BOSNIAN SERBS HOLDING GROUND Bosnian Serbs held their positions on two strategic mountains and were reported to be moving more weapons and troops toward territory under Government control. A3 Mediators in Geneva postponed peace talks on Bosnia. A3

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the Delta Clipper Experimental rocket misstated its flight ability. As noted in the related article in Science Times, the vehicle is suborbital; it cannot reach space. The rocket is a prototype for larger single-stage rockets that could reach space.

title: Mason Working Hard To Lift Knicks a Notch
description: Some people will go a long way just for a pickup game.

title: James H. Ahmann, 62, Pilot and Air Force General
description: Lieut. Gen. James H. Ahmann of the Air Force, a highly decorated Vietnam War pilot who helped plan military fighter planes, died at his home in Vienna, Va., on Sunday. He was 62.

title: SoHo, Sidewalks And Small Cafes: Oh, So Romantic! Oh, So Illegal!
description: FEW scenes in New York may be as romantic as an outdoor cafe table in SoHo. But to a small group of artists and urban pioneers who moved to this once-decrepit neighborhood before it became gentrified and swamped by shoppers, nothing has been more disturbing than the proliferation of unenclosed sidewalk cafe tables that, with their umbrellas, sprout up like giant portobello mushrooms each night.

title: I.A.A.F. Won't Review Krabbe Case Now
description: Ignoring appeals and pressure from Germany, world track and field officials have refused to discuss the case of the world-champion sprinter, KATRIN KRABBE, who remains suspended for doping.

title: Accounts
description: * EON Corp., Reston, Va., to Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG, New York, as the first agency to handle the interactive television service's consumer and business-to-business advertising. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. * Consolidated Shoe Inc., Lynchburg, Va., to Earle Palmer Brown/New York, as the first agency to handle the consumer account for its Nicole shoe line. The agency already handles Nicole's trade account. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Giuliani Outlines Plan to Stir Economy
description: Looking toward the future by casting back to the revitalization of New York City's economy in the early 1980's, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor, yesterday released an extensive plan for the city's economy that stressed cutting the city work force by more than 16 percent, tax relief and an end to some fines that he said were driving small businesses from the city.

title: Where to Drop a Lisp Or Pick Up an Accent
description: Weeks into an attempt to expunge her German accent, Marietta Maxime was still struggling with her sitchoovashun.

title: Imcera Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 3,100,000 and $ 6,000,000, for the quarter and year, respectively. Net charges for discontinued operations were primarily for litigation costs.The latest quarter also included net charge of $ 80,600,000 which included charges of $ 8.5 million, or $ 5.4 million aftertax, related to incremental charges for FAS Nos. 106, 112, the unfavorable effects of which were partially offset by the favorable aftertax impact of FAS 109, or $ 1.6 million, or 2 cents a share.c-Net income and included income of $ 900,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and a loss of $ 1,300,000 in the year, both from discontinued operations. Net charges were primarily from the effects of the disposal of the balance of Imcera's investment in IMC Fertilizer Group.Latest quarter and year's loss from continuing operations of $ 199,900,000 and $ 113,800,000, respectively, both included restructuring charges of $ 334.1 million, or $ 242.2 million aftertax and charges of $ 8.5 million, or $ 5.4 million after tax, from the adoption of FAS Nos. 106, 109. The year also included an expense of $ 5.5 million, or $ 3.4 million aftertax, from executive resignations resulting from the performance of its Pitman-Moore unit.Year-ago income from continuing operations of $ 42,800,000, or 55 cents a share, and $ 128,800,000, or $ 1.65 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, both included charges of $ 12.8 million, or $ 7.9 million aftertax, for restructuring costs which were virtually offset by adjustments made to certain excess accruals established at the time its Pitman-Moore unit acquired Coopers Animal Health in July 1989.Also, charges of $ 3.8 million, or $ 2.4 million aftertax, related to a joint venture with Hercules Inc.'s flavor businesses; and gains from the sale of investments of $ 3.7 million, or $ 2.3 million aftertax, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 10.7 million, or $ 6.7 million aftertax, or 8 cents a share, in the year.Fiscal 1992 sales results included charges of $ 3.8 million, or $ 2.4 million aftertax, from the combination of the company's Mallinckrodt unit and Hercules Inc.'s flavors businesses in a joint venture.

title: Books of The Times; Of Islam, Fundamentalism and Western Values
description: The New Cold War? Religious Nationalism Confronts the Secular State By Mark Juergensmeyer 292 pages. University of California Press. $25. Islam and the West By Bernard Lewis 217 pages. Oxford University Press. $25.

title: INSIDE
description: Europe Losing Faith In Political Leaders

title: Military Regimen for Teen-Age Dropouts
description: It was 6:59 A.M. and Arthur Cole, 17 years old, was due in formation in front of his National Guard barracks at 0700 hours. The prospects were not good. Arthur couldn't find his regulation shoes (he was wearing sandals) and he couldn't find his Guard-issued pants (his bermudas were hanging so low his underwear was identifiable).

title: Fortay Sues Miami, His Old School
description: Rutgers quarterback BRYAN FORTAY has filed a Federal lawsuit charging that the University of Miami, his old school, didn't keep a promise to make him a starter and thereby hurt his chances for a professional career.

title: SHARES OF FERROFLUIDICS FALL ON NEWS OF S.E.C. INQUIRY
description: Shares of the Ferrofluidics Corporation fell 21.4 percent after the company said the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating the possibility of securities-law violations at the company. The stock fell $3.125, to $11.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Sigmund Wesolowski, 70, Dies; A Chest Specialist and Professor
description: Dr. Sigmund Adam Wesolowski, a chest specialist known for his skill in treating complicated vascular heart diseases like arteriosclerosis, died on Sunday at Youville Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 70 and lived in Lynnfield, Mass.

title: ARC International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $ 173,187, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 98,233, or 1 cent a share, in the 6 months.

title: All Rape Is 'Real' Rape
description: This summer, when "whirlpooling" replaced "wilding" as the latest media-designated sex crime, the peer group that spawned such gang assaults rallied to their defense. It blamed the victims ("girls have to know how to take care of themselves!") and excused the offenders ("this was just innocent horseplay!"). I toured this country recently and learned again that such prejudices pollute far more than New York City's public swimming pools.

title: Europe's Worry: A Generation of Leaders Not Up to the Task?
description: Confronted by political scandal, recession and the erosion of familiar comforts, Western Europeans have come to sense that the very people they chose to solve their problems have been in power too long to steer a dejected Continent through the shifting shoals that mark the close of the 20th century.

title: Pratt Hotel Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a hot air balloon accident on Sunday near Aspen, Colo., listed one passenger erroneously in some editions among the dead. The passenger, Dr. Henry Pendergrass, professor of radiology at Vanderbilt Medical Center in Nashville, survived.

title: CRSS Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 8,575,000 from cumulative effect of adoption of new accounting standards for postretirement benefits, income tax accounting and postemployment benefits.c-Net lossd-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 15,399,000 in the quarter and $ 16,910,000 in the year, and the quarter also included a $ 5.3 million charge, or 40 cents a share, for cost reduction program.

title: Demjanjuk Verdict Points Up Complicity; Fight Return to U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Edunetics Ltd. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest shares outstanding reflects increase in weighted average number of shares outstanding due to the company's initial public offering, which was completed in April 1993.Edunetics said that the increase in revenues for the second quarter was primarily attributable to revenue recognized of about $ 1.5 million under an $ 8.9 million contract received from Plano Independent School District in Plano, Texas, during the second quarter.

title: Thermo Electron reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-After a charge of $ 1,438,000 from an adjustment in accounting.

title: METROPOLITAN GOLF REPORT
description: The United States Amateur

title: Scitex Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 4,901,000, or 12 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in method of accounting.

title: Outlook Is Uncertain on Revenue Sharing by Owners
description: Richard Ravitch, the architect of baseball's plan to increase revenue sharing among the 28 clubs, can count on a certain number of votes for adoption of some sort of plan. But it's the votes he isn't certain of that will determine the outcome of the owners' meeting in Kohler, Wis., that begins today.

title: The McDade Exception
description: House Republicans took a long-overdue step last week: They voted to require members who have been indicted to relinquish leadership posts on committees until their cases are resolved. Eager to avoid criticism of their party, they endorsed the sound rule embraced long ago by the House Democratic Caucus.

title:
Real Estate;
Nigeria is Seeking Tenants for its New $32 Million Tower on Second Avenue Near the United Nations.
description: NOW that the Government of Nigeria has moved its New York offices to a $32 million tower it built at 828 Second Avenue, at the northeast corner of 44th Street, it is looking for tenants to fill 3 of 22 floors.

title: Norman's Willing to Let Past Stay Put
description: Greg Norman did a major makeover on his personal history by charging to a British Open victory last month. This week at the 75th P.G.A. Championship, at the Inverness Club, he can take an entire chapter and rewrite it.

title: In Summer Doldrums, Stocks Are Mixed
description: Stocks were mixed yesterday, taking their cue from a bond market now working its way through the Government's quarterly auction of new debt securities.

title: AMRE Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Included recognition of $ 2.5 million in tax refunds resulting from the settlement of an Internal Revenue Service audit covering years 1986 through 1990 in both the quarter and 6 months.c-Net income

title: Counsel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 21,500,000 for the quarter and $ 22,100,000 for the 6 months.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 3,681,000, or 34 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Intertape Polymer Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Primark Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 459,000 in the quarter and $ 408,000 in the 6 months.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 612,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 836,000, or 4 cents a share, in the 6 months.Preferred-share dividends were $ 358,000 in the latest second quarter, compared with $ 337,000 in the year-ago period, and $ 710,000 in the latest 6 months, against $ 666,000 in the year-ago period.The latest periods included foreign currency losses of $ 4,016,000 in the quarter and $ 2,938,000 in the 6 months.

title: Giardia Test Will Cut Waiting Time
description: DOCTORS have long been frustrated by the difficulty of diagnosing giardia, a common parasitic infection of the intestine that causes diarrhea, bloating, nausea, stomach pain and fatigue. The current test is so unreliable that patients frequently suffer the debilitating symptoms for weeks or months before they test positive and are treated for the disease.

title: Planning Director Candidate Named for Suffolk County
description: Moving swiftly to fill a major post, the Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, nominated Stephen M. Jones of Bayport today to become the county's director of planning.

title: Overseas Shipholding reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gain on disposal of vessels of $ 3,967,000, or 12 cents a share, in the quarter and 6 months.c-Afer a gain of $ 16 million, or 49 cents a share, reflecting the adoption of accounting change.Provisions for income taxes in the latest periods were $ 2 million in the quarter and $ 3.4 million in the 6 months, compared with $ 375,000 and $ 5,225,000, respectively, in year-ago periods.

title: American Oil & Gas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: American Oil & Gas said that the decrease in earnings was due primarily to a $ 2.9 million reduction in gross margin on sales of natural gas. The reduced margins are attributed to fixed-price contracts.

title: New Pregnancy Hope: a Single Sperm
description: BELGIAN scientists have invented a new treatment for male infertility that they say may allow virtually any man, no matter how few or misshapen or immobile his sperm cells, to father a child.

title: Region Stands To Gain Little In New Budget
description: New Jersey, New York and Connecticut will be among the states that benefit least, while paying the most, under the economic plan that President Clinton signed into law today.

title: After Her Pivotal 'Yes' on Budget, Now the Fallout
description: A vision of the future stared back at Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky from a table at Nick's Pizzeria the other day, and it did not appear altogether happy.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Chase Manhattan Corp., New York, is offering $200 million of 6.75 percent subordinated notes due in 2008 at 99.58 to yield 6.795 percent through Lehman Brothers. The noncallable notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's and Duff & Phelps.

title: Biosys (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included special charge of $ 3,692,000 resulting from management's election to expense purchased research and development technology from the AgriSense acquisition in both the quarter and 6 months.

title: The California Phone Rush Is On
description: Not since the breakup of the Bell System monopoly 10 years ago has the telecommunications industry seen such upheaval as is taking place in California, where companies will soon be allowed to compete to carry short-haul toll calls that are now the sole province of local phone companies.

title: Standard Commercial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $ 15.2 million after-tax restructuring charge, and after a gain of $ 23,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting changes.c-Net income and included extraordinary benefit of tax-loss carryforwards of $ 181,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about Western European curbs on immigrants color-coded Finland incorrectly. It should have been shown as part of Western Europe.

title: Serbs Said to Send More Troops and Arms to Sarajevo
description: Despite renewed assurances by Serbian nationalists that their troops were withdrawing from two strategic mountains overlooking Sarajevo, the units held their positions today and were reported to be moving more heavy weapons and hundreds of fresh troops forward toward the small pocket of territory that remains under Bosnian Government control.

title: Jersey Shore Beach Food: Just a Summer Love?
description: NEW JERSEY may be famous for its tomatoes, but when summer is over, they may not be the food vacationers remember best.

title: Vigoro Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included charges of $ 1,407,000 in the quarter and $ 1,969,000 in the year, related to the early retirement of debt.

title: DeWolfe Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: DeWolfe Cos. said that the 6 months' earnings in 1992 included a tax benefit of $ 107,000 from net operating loss carryforward.

title: Caller I.D. on the Farm
description: A.T.& T. and a group of small telephone companies yesterday announced a plan to provide hard-to-reach rural customers with new services like Caller I.D., which are becoming routine to city dwellers.

title: Big Victory for American Airlines in Fare Suit
description: After an intense four-week trial, jurors decided in less than four hours today that American Airlines did not try to drive weaker competitors out of business with "predatory" prices during the air fare war last summer.

title: Reading & Bates reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss, which included accretion in redemption price of redeemable stocks: $ 1.5 million in the quarter and $ 2.9 million in the 6 months.

title: Thermo Instrument Systems Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
Sigma-Aldrich (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 10,806,000 from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Fatal Motorcycle Accident
description: An elderly woman was struck and killed on a Manhattan street last night by a motorcyclist driving with a suspended license, the police said. The woman, Maria Perez, 82, was hit about 6 P.M. while crossing West 177th Street at Audubon Avenue in Washington Heights, the police said. The motorcycle driver, Benjamin Herrera, 22, was arrested on a charge of driving with a suspended license but was not charged with any other crimes in connection with the accident, the police said. Mrs. Perez was taken to Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital, were she was pronounced dead. Mr. Herrera, who crashed into a parked car after striking the woman, suffered minor injuries. He was in stable condition at Harlem Hospital.

title: Bridge
description: An unusual feature of the Summer Nationals in Washington last month was a special morning game in aid of the local Children's Hospital in which celebrities from other fields played with an expert. Pledges from other players were based on the scores of the celebrities, who included Representative Jim Leach , Republican of Iowa, Pauline Betz Addie, former United States and Wimbledon champion, and Benjamin C. Bradlee, former executive editor of The Washington Post.

title: NEW RULES TIGHTEN ACCESS TO SHELTER IN NEW YORK CITY
description: New York City will soon refuse to shelter families just because they say they are homeless. Those who could continue to live with friends or family, or who abandon their apartments because of crime and drug-dealing in their neighborhoods, will be turned away, city officials said yesterday.

title: Personal Health
description: MOST parents of infants and preschoolers have no memory of summers when children were kept out of swimming pools for fear of catching polio. Indeed, a 1993 Gallup poll shows that nearly half of parents today are unaware that polio is a contagious disease. Nor do they know firsthand the terrors of breath-robbing whooping cough, the often fatal paralysis of tetanus or the sometimes fatal throat infection caused by diphtheria. Many do not know that measles can cause life-threatening encephalitis and mental retardation.

title: Former Analyst Is Found Guilty
description: Edward Scherer, a former analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, was convicted on Monday on charges that he made more than $1 million in illegal trading profits for himself and two other people.

title: A Man Marries a Man? Print It!
description: When a bride-to-be brings the announcement of her coming wedding to be published in the Sunday Lifestyles section of the Salina Journal, we don't demand to see a marriage license. We don't discriminate against second marriages or interracial unions.

title: JAPANESE PREMIER TACKLES U.S. TIES
description: Japan's new Prime Minister used his first news conference today to emphasize his eagerness to improve strained relations and reduce Japan's huge trade surplus with the United States, but he rejected most of the tools President Clinton has insisted on using to do the job.

title: 2 Executives Open A New York Shop
description: Two executives from Towne, Silverstein, Rotter Inc. in New York have left to open their own shop.

title: Electro Rent (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included write-offs of obsolete computer hardware and software and receivables, and store closure costs, totaling $ 1.9 million in both the quarter and year. The year also included a gain from an accounting change of $ 2,591,000, or 45 cents a share.

title: Anangel-American Shipholdings Ltd. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
National Vision Associates (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures represented pro forma figures to reflect the increase in weighted average number of shares from the company's initial public offering in May of 1992, and a secondary offering in October 1992.

title: Starrett (L.S.) (N) reports earnings for Year to June 26
description: b-After a charge of $ 7,729,000 from the cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change.

title: Ranger Oil Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mood Ellington: The Faithful Gather
description: Duke Ellington is Russia to the Napoleon of his biographers and fans. Nineteen years after his death, he still hasn't been the subject of a decent biography, though rumor has it that a new one in the works will remedy that. The most basic information -- which of his pieces were played when, and by whom -- is lost in the shadows of memory, yet to be clarified. His discography, 534 pages long, is a swamp of official recordings, airchecks made from radio broadcasts, V-disks made for the armed forces during World War II, live recordings and Ellingtonian revisions of older material. There are 183 recorded versions of "Perdido" listed. Try to get a handle on that.

title: Virgin Megastore in Paris
description: The Virgin Group, the British music retailer, has decided to stop doing business on Sundays at its flagship Paris store, Patrick Zelnik, the chairman of Virgin's French subsidiary, Virgin France, said today.

title: Market Place; At a Rail Car Maker, Lawsuits Test the Importance of Being Earnest.
description: "THE company is not currently involved in any material lawsuits."

title: U.S. Spied on Its World War II Allies
description: The United States spied on its World War II allies, breaking their codes and intercepting their secret diplomatic communiques, newly declassified documents show.

title: Dollar Rallies on Possibility Of Rate Cuts by Europeans
description: The dollar rallied against most European currencies yesterday amid speculation that high unemployment would force several European Community nations to cut interest rates to stimulate economic growth.

title: U.S. Joins Investigation Into Asbestos in Schools
description: Federal prosecutors announced yesterday that they would look into why asbestos inspections in New York City's public schools were so shoddy, as city investigators said for the first time that their own inquiry includes other companies involved in the asbestos program besides the one publicly cited.

title: U.S. Grants $13 Million More For I.B.M.'s Supercomputer
description: I.B.M.'s fledgling supercomputer business got a lift yesterday as two Federal agencies awarded a major grant to the Cornell Theory Center, a research proving ground for the powerful machines that are expected to replace mainframes some day.

title: Parker Hannifin reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes pretax provisions for restructuring of $ 13,333,000 in the quarter and $ 22,879,000 for the year.c-Included pretax provisions for restructuring of $ 10,734,000 in the quarter and $ 14,798,000 for the year. The year was also after an extraordinary net charge of $ 52,261,000, which comprised a charge of $ 60,619,000 from a change in accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions, and a gain of $ 8,358,000, or 17 cents a share, from a change in accounting for income taxes.The company said that it changed the fiscal year-end of subsidiaries outside North America to June 30 from May 31. It said that this resulted in an increase of $ 40.1 million in sales and a decrease of $ 1.5 million, or 3 cents a share, in net earnings.

title: A Brighter Day for Legal Services
description: Lawyer-bashing is an old story for the underpaid, overworked attorneys who represent the poor in more than 300 poverty law offices under the federally funded Legal Services Corporation. For eight years the Reagan Administration pummeled the program with abuse and tried to kill it, and for four years the Bush Administration neglected it. Now President Clinton has wisely chosen a new board of directors committed to breathing renewed life into the program.

title: Find Options On Hillview, Dinkins Says
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins publicly instructed his environmental commissioner yesterday to look into less expensive ways to cap the city's Hillview Reservoir as an alternative to the current plan for a concrete deck with a reflecting pool on top.

title: Brinker International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1993.

title: Mips Names I.B.M. Officer As President
description: Raising the ante in microprocessor competition, Mips Technologies Inc. today named Tom Whiteside, the director of I.B.M.'s RISC processor development, to be its president.

title: Officer on Drug Duty Wounded in Shooting
description: A police officer trying to serve a search warrant on suspected drug dealers in a Washington Heights apartment yesterday morning was wounded in the leg when one of the suspects ambushed him, the police said.

title: Teen-Ager Testifies That Off-Duty Police Officer Threw First Blow In Clash
description: A teen-ager who prosecutors say was criminally beaten by two off-duty New York City police officers after he slashed the face of a third off-duty officer, testified yesterday that he had wielded his razor blade only after the man he cut had punched him.

title: Mitchell Trims Down, Inflates Expectations
description: First-round draft choice, first season, first regular-season game, first pass reception: Johnny Mitchell had the football, a 23-yard gain and -- ouch! -- a shoulder injury that kept him out of action for the next six weeks.

title: Where Arab Militants Train and Wait
description: For nearly a decade, this frontier city of densely packed mud houses skewered by narrow lanes, vast suburbs of pastel-hued homes and streets crowded with four-wheel drive vehicles and donkey carts, was home to spies, military planners, guerrilla commanders and would-be political leaders, all intent on driving out the Soviet Army.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Takeover Rumblings at Rodman
description: A power struggle at Rodman & Renshaw Capital Group Inc. is threatening to erupt into a takeover battle featuring former executives from two of Wall Street's onetime biggest deal makers.

title: Metrocall Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are pro forma. Metrocall completed an initial public offering of 2.7 million common shares at $ 13 a share in July 1993. Pro forma net income for the latest second quarter was $ 500,930 after adjustment for applicable interest expense, while pro forma net income for the latest 6 months was $ 1,019,106.The pro forma weighted average shares outstanding has been adjusted for the number of shares related to the forgiveness of notes receivable on shares granted to certain officers of the company effected upon the completion of the company's IPO.Also, the estimated number of shares that the company would need to issue to pay distributions to the company's pre-offering stockholders and to repay a portion of borrowings under the company's existing credit agreement.

title: AMSOUTH TO ACQUIRE CITIZENS NATIONAL IN STOCK DEAL
description: The Amsouth Bancorp of Birmingham, Ala., signed a definitive agreement yesterday to buy the six-branch Citizens National Corporation of Naples, Fla., for $48.8 million in stock. Amsouth said the purchase would expand its network in one of the five fastest-growing cities in the nation and complement its pending acquisition of Parkway Bank in nearby Fort Myers. Amsouth said it would exchange $11.25 of its stock for each share of Citizens National.

title: New Polio Shot May Be Safer
description: A NEW, beefed-up version of the old polio vaccine, based on killed virus, may provide better protection against this disease and, at the same time, prevent the rare cases of paralytic polio that occur among the recipients of the currently used Sabin vaccine, an oral vaccine made from attenuated live virus, according to a study in the current issue of the Journal of Infectious Diseases.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON, who was born in Park Ridge, Ill., has inspired a team of songwriters in nearby Chicago. Their new song, "Do the Hillary," begins like this: "Take your man/by the hand/hold him tight/it's your right."

title: Boys of 50's Brooklyn, Graying but Still Game
description: BACK then in that time of egg creams and lime rickeys when they were being boys together, when they were first learning about sin, when their parents were worried about what would become of them, back then in the 50's, Flink's was the center of everything.

title: Crabs in Their Glory
description: CHEFS looking for novel ways to present soft-shell crabs sometimes smother them with flavors that overwhelm their delicate sweetness.

title: Lehman Bros. Appointment
description: Dexter Senft, one of the Wall Street "rocket scientists" of a decade and more ago, who transformed bond trading from a seat-of-the-pants business into one relying on computers and mathematical models, has joined Lehman Brothers as a managing director in charge of quantitative research.

title: Jeremiah Kaplan, Veteran Executive In Publishing, 67
description: Jeremiah Kaplan, a former president of two New York-based publishing companies, the Macmillan Publishing Company and then Simon & Schuster Inc. died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 67 and had homes on the East Side of Manhattan and in Holden, Mass.

title: American Exploration Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 9.9 million from a settlement related to a gas contract, partially offset by $ 6.6 million of charges related to the sale of the company's Canadian oil and gas assets in both the quarter and 6 months.c-Net loss

title: CII Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and the 6 months is after an extraordinary credit of $ 457,000, or 6 cents a share.The company said the losses in the year-earlier periods reflect increased loss reserves as a result of the deteriorating workers' compensation environment, mainly in southern California.

title: 'New' Immigrants Closely Follow the Pattern of Predecessors; Not Loud or Violent
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/City Opera; 'Tosca,' In a Moody Revival
description: The City Opera's 50th anniversary season has opened with a heavy salvo of Puccini: "La Boheme," "Madama Butterfly" and, on Saturday night, "Tosca." The last two are both revivals of productions by Frank Corsaro, and their variable success illustrates the challenge posed by Puccini's adventurous conservatism.

title: Ohio State Coach Testifies in Jackson Trial
description: The Ohio State basketball coach, RANDY AYERS, testified yesterday in Columbus, Ohio, that one of four people accusing the former Buckeye basketball star, JIM JACKSON, of waving a gun at them admitted he wasn't certain Jackson had a gun.

title: Gymboree Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Molex Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 3,605,000 on the adoption of accounting changes for postretirement benefits other than pensions.Share earnings and shares outstanding were restated for the 25 percent stock dividend effective November 1992.The latest year and the 1992 year were restated to reflect adoption of accounting change retroactive to July 31, 1992.Molex said that currency translation raised net revenue by $ 5.8 million and net income by $ 900,000 in the latest fourth quarter, and lifted net revenue by $ 20.5 million and net income by $ 2.7 million for the year.

title: Trichardtsdal Journal; A Farmer, but Not Exactly a Boer. You See . . .
description: On the day Rex Mametja was inducted into the farming fraternity of this tropical hamlet, he hovered near the door of the planters' hangout, the Ofcolaco Club, ready to flee across the cricket pitch if necessary.

title: Reform for the Public Lands
description: Resurrecting a promise he had shelved under pressure from Western lawmakers, President Clinton proposes to double grazing fees and tighten supervision for America's vast public lands. While environmental purists might want higher fees and stiffer rules, the new plan is a wholesome break with historical leniency toward the private use of public resources.

title: 30-Year Bond Continues to Gain
description: The Treasury market appeared to take a breather yesterday as the Government began its quarterly auction of notes and bonds.

title: How Bosnia's Saviors Became Its Jailers
description: Faced with the real possibility of American or NATO air strikes against Bosnian Serb positions, and with Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic's refusal to return to peace talks in Geneva until the Serbs vacate positions around Sarajevo, the United Nations acted. It made a deal with Bosnian Serb leaders to move U.N. troops into the strategic sites while the Serb forces gradually pull out. But as has been the case so often in the war, the U.N. moves have only ended up helping the Bosnian Serbs.

title: Looking to Advice from the Alumni
description: DONNA DE VARONA sees them as an untapped treasure, BILL TOOMEY as a great and dormant asset. They are the 9,500 or so American alumni of previous Olympic Games.

title: Demjanjuk Verdict Points Up Complicity
description: To the Editor:

title: While Watching on Sideline, Roberts Has No Worry Signs
description: Giants offensive lineman William Roberts watched practice today, saying that he was eager to return to the team and that he was not concerned about his latest episode of atrial fibrillation, or rapid heartbeat.

title: Red Sox and Viola Treat It Like a Big Game
description: The Yankees kept assuring themselves that this was not a really important series. Three games in August against the Red Sox with first-place implications for both teams, not important? These were the Red Sox. This was Fenway Park. Scalpers were asking $75 for a bleacher ticket. This game carried more impact for both teams than any since 1988, even if the Yankees were reluctant to admit it.

title: International Colin Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Campus Journal; Happy Endings in Class By Studying Cinderella
description: Rossini composed an opera about her, Julie Andrews played her in a Rodgers and Hammerstein musical, and Jerry Lewis played a male version in a movie. She's been analyzed by Freudians and Jungians.

title: Helm Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,918,000 in the quarter and $ 2,986,000 in the year, and an extraordinary gain on investments of $ 27,000 in both the quarter and year.c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 5,195,000 and $ 7,787,000 in the quarter and year, respectively, and the quarter also included an extraordinary charge of $ 305,000 from adjustment of operating loss carryforwards.

title: Goldfield Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 917,500, from a cumulative effect of change in accounting principles.c-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 26 about an American warplane that fired on a missile battery in southern Iraq misidentified the authority that barred Iraqi flights over the area. The ban was imposed by the United States, Britain and France, not the United Nations.

title: Somali Showdown
description: The American determination to arrest a fugitive Somali clan leader underscores how the United Nations mission in Somalia has evolved from one of guarding and providing relief aid to aggressive military enforcement.

title: Review/Music; Samples of the Baroque, Paired at Mostly Mozart
description: In its most avant-garde swipe yet at the thematic programming trend, the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center opened its Mozart and Haydn Week on Monday evening with a double bill that brought together Charpentier's "Acteon" and Purcell's "Dido and Aeneas," performed not by the festival's resident players, but by William Christie and Les Arts Florissants. It was, in effect, Not Mozart and Haydn Week at the Not Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: On Eve of Strike, Nigeria Detains Opponents
description: Nigeria's military Government has detained dozens of opponents and imposed tight controls on the press as a three-day protest of the annulment of June's elections approaches.

title: Bosnia Mediators Call Off Talks Until Serbs Quit Mountains
description: Indirectly endorsing Bosnian Muslim demands, the international mediators on Bosnia and Herzegovina said today that they would not reconvene peace talks until Serbian forces withdrew from two strategic mountains overlooking Sarajevo.

title: Serbs Must Withdraw Promptly Or Face Air Strikes, U.S. Insists
description: The United States intensified pressure on the Bosnian Serbs today by explicitly warning that they could face a NATO attack unless they moved quickly to abandon positions on two strategic mountains near Sarajevo.

title: Midwest Grain Products (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a net gain of $ 1,665,000, or 17 cents a share, from discontinued operations, which included $ 616,000 from operations of McCormick Distilling, and a gain of $ 1,049,000 from its sale. The period also included a loss of $ 2,241,000 from change in accounting for postretirement benefits and gain of $ 2,182,000 from change in accounting for income taxes.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 531,000, or 6 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 1,294,000, or 13 cents a share, in the year.Year-ago discontinued operations included operations of McCormick Distilling.

title: Hope Seen for Curbing Youth Violence
description: Although statistics show that violence is rising among American youths, a panel of psychologists released a report yesterday offering an optimistic view of what might be done to reverse the bloody tide.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading in some copies on Monday about a girl in Sullivan County, N.Y., who died of rabies drew an incorrect medical conclusion. A New York State Health Department official pointed out in a letter to The Times that once symptoms appear, rabies is invariably fatal. Thus the fact that doctors did not immediately recognize the girl's symptoms made no difference in the outcome, and did not lead to the death.

title: J. P. Morgan
description: J. P. Morgan & Company's operations could get a lift from low interest rates in Europe, according to new research by Carla D'Arista, a Bear, Stearns analyst. The bank's earnings prospects appear bright because it generates the bulk of its business from Europe. The analyst estimated that J. P. Morgan would earn $7.70 a share this year and $8.25 a share in 1994.

title: Sex, Hollywood and August
description: If it weren't the season for heat, bugs, downpours, droughts and zucchini, if her alleged clients were Kansas City car dealers or Jersey City butchers, if her name was -- let's say, Louise -- the story would be somewhere between the horoscope and the help wanteds. But it is August, the alleged clients are Hollywood high rollers, her name is Heidi and we are talking harmonious convergence. We are talking front page. We are talking Heidi Ho!

title: Corrections
description: A subheading on Thursday with an article about a judge's order of fines against New York City and his finding of four officials in contempt over lack of progress in housing the homeless misattributed a quotation. It was the plaintiff's lawyer, Steven Banks, and not the judge, who said, "Senior city officials have acted as if they were above the law."

title: BioSafety Systems reports earnings for Year to June 30
60-Minute Gourmet
description: AS American cooks look for low-fat ways of cooking, some happy discoveries are being made. Vegetable purees can make delightful substitutes for cream-based sauces, herb-enlivened vinaigrettes (hot and cold) help wean us off butter and lean meats like turkey can be transformed into some memorable dishes.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In 1941, HARRY CALLAHAN was working in Detroit as a clerk for the Chrysler Motor Company, and in his spare time he was trying to figure out what to do with his camera. Then Ansel Adams came to town to show his pictures and talk about photography, and Mr. Callahan's life changed forever.

title: Hollywood Casino (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Grand Valley Gas Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Wine Talk
description: A FEW wine people were relaxing on the terrace at Chateau Prieure-Lichine, in Bordeaux, one sultry day last month.

title: Joseph Salvaggio, Television Executive, 48
description: Joseph Salvaggio, a cable television executive, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 48 and lived in Manhattan and Sag Harbor.

title: Advertising; Here's JayDaveConanChevy! Hard Sell for Late-Night TV
description: Don't ask what Jay, David, Chevy, Conan and Arsenio are doing to lure viewers for the mega-gabfest coming to late-night television.

title: Olivia L. Gilliam, 55, A Foundation Director
description: Olivia L. Gilliam, a foundation executive, died on Sunday at her home in Great Barrington, Mass. She was 55 and also lived in Manhattan.

title: CRAY BUYS SUPERCOMPUTER VENTURE'S TECHNOLOGIES
description: The last vestiges of Supercomputer Systems Inc., a partnership between I.B.M. and Steve S. Chen to build the world's fastest computer, have been acquired by Cray Research Inc. of Eagan, Minn. Terms of the deal to buy certain technologies were not disclosed.

title: Eating Well
description: THE American Heart Association is trying once again to put its torch-and-heart logo on packages of food that meet its dietary guidelines. It is an effort, the association says, to help consumers choose healthful foods and not spend a lot of time doing it.

title: Paragon Trade Brands Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: Reflecting the latest 6 months and both year-ago periods--Paragon Trade Brands became an independent public company in late January 1993 after an initial public offering by Weyerhaeuser Co. Prior to the offering, Paragon Trade conducted its business as the private label diaper business of Weyerhaeuser.

title: Huntco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary charge of $ 484,000.

description: It must be August: Cartier has told its caterer to hold the caviar and Champagne and bring out the hot dogs and soda.

title: MAXUS SHARES RISE ON EXPECTATIONS FOR COLOMBIA WELL
description: The shares of the Maxus Energy Corporation jumped 24.6 percent yesterday as investors speculated that the company had a major discovery in Colombia. The company's stock jumped $1.875, to $9.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, where the company's trading volume of almost 7.4 million shares was the second largest of the day.

title: Executive Changes
description: ALCO STANDARD CORP., Valley Forge, Pa., a paper and office products distribution company, appointed John E. Stuart president and chief executive. ATLANTIC GROUP, New York, a unit of Time Warner, named Tony O'Brien senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Blessing (or Burden?) of a Child's Chess Gift
description: "Searching for Bobby Fischer" isn't about Mr. Fischer, but it's well named. The film tells the story of Josh Waitzkin, a gifted young chess player growing up in the shadow of the legendary boy wonder, the one whose name is still mentioned in awestruck tones. Yet Mr. Fischer, who is seen here in old news clips as a boy playing against rows of different grown-up opponents and otherwise dazzling the chess establishment, is as well remembered for arrogance and eccentricity as he is for brilliance. Hovering over this absorbing story, the image of Mr. Fischer embodies genius as a double-edged sword.

title: Knape & Vogt Manufacturing (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of $ 963,000.Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in September 1992.

title: Schult Homes Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
Using Old Art of Stained Glass to Train the Young
description: When Norman Sealy started restoring stained glass at a church this summer, his mother began thinking of him as a saint. "My mother is very religious," he explained.

title: Home Retailer Puts Account in Review
description: Home Base Inc., a home-improvement warehouse retail chain based in Fullerton, Calif., said yesterday that it had placed its $15 million to $20 million broadcast advertising account in review. Since December 1991, creative work and production on the account had been handled by the Colby Agency of Los Angeles, while J. L. P. Media Inc. of New York handled media buying. Neither agency will participate in the review.

title: Nature Food Centres Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 26,000 in the quarter and $ 51,000, or 1 cent a share, in the 6 months.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 129,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 164,000, or 4 cents a share, in the 6 months.Nature Food Centres said that results from 1993's first half and all of 1992 do not assume the company had already merged with Revere Fund and had acquired Nutrition World.The company said that on a pro forma basis, assuming it had already both merged with Revere Fund and acquired Nutrition World as of the beginning of 1992, the year-ago second quarter would have had net income of $ 723,000, or 14 cents a share.The 6 months' net of 1993 would have been $ 1,643,000, or 33 cents a share, compared with net income of $ 1,586,000, or 32 cents a share, in the year-earlier period.

title: No Headline
description: "I was not meant for the job or the spotlight of public life in Washington. Here ruining people is considered sport." -- VINCENT W. FOSTER JR. [ A1:4. ]

title: Correction: Chocolate Quatre-Quarts
description: A recipe for chocolate quatre-quarts with an article on July 14 about summer desserts made from fresh berries, or to be used with them, misstated the baking temperature. Here is a corrected version: Chocolate Quatre-Quarts Total time: 2 hours, plus overnight refrigeration 3 ounces semisweet or bittersweet chocolate, melted in a double boiler or for 2 minutes in a microwave oven 1/2 cup all-purpose flour 1/2 cup cake flour 1/4 teaspoon baking soda Large pinch kosher salt 3 large eggs, room temperature, separated 1 cup unsalted butter, room temperature, plus small amount for the pan 3/4 cup granulated sugar.

title: Joan Walden Fleischman, Social Worker, 61
description: Joan Walden Fleischman, a social worker who specialized in working with families with abused or neglected children, died on Monday at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle. She was 61 and lived in Glen Rock, N.J.

title: A Celebrated Tourist at Hall of Fame
description: The heavyweight champion RIDDICK BOWE celebrated his 26th birthday yesterday with a visit to the International Boxing Hall of Fame in Canastota, N.Y.

title: Ann Taylor Stores Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 10,496,000 which reflects aftertax charge from refinancings in both the quarter and 6 months.c-Net incomeAnn Taylor Stores reported that during the second quarter, its Ann Taylor Inc. unit completed a refinancing of its long-term debt, including the isssuance of $ 110 million principal amount of 83/4 percent subordinate notes due 2000; the repayment of its former bank credit agreement and its replacement with a new bank credit agreement with a term loan availability of $ 80 million and revolving credit facility of $ 55 million.It also included the acquisition of $ 24,941,000 principal amount of its senior subordinated notes due 1999 and $ 14,829,000 face amount of its subordinated notes due 1999, and the discharge of its remaining obligations on these two issues of high-yield notes. These transactions resulted in an extraordinary charge of $ 16,148,000, or $ 10,496,000 after taxes.

title: Louise Horwood, 102, Public-Health Worker
description: Louise Pierce Horwood, a retired public-health worker and civic leader, died on Thursday at a hospital in Hamilton, Ontario. She was 102 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Suit Says Pregnancy Led to Job Loss
description: JoMarie DeGioia says she was so devastated when she was dismissed from a part-time job at a Weight Watchers center, it took her four years to fight back.

description: Companies

title: Sports of The Times; Luxury-Box Fever Kills 'Ball Parks'
description: ONE of the saddest things I have heard this summer is a congressional proposal for the Department of Interior to purchase four historic ball parks when they are no longer needed for major league baseball.

description: To the Editor:

description: Blue Jays 6, Twins 3

title: President Signs Budget Bill, Then Turns to Next Battles
description: Rolling out all the imperial trappings of the executive branch onto the South Lawn of the White House, President Clinton today signed the budget bill for which he had fought so hard and scolded Republicans in Congress, saying they had shown "partisan bitterness and rancor" in last week's narrow victory.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: EMPIRE PLANS STAFF REDUCTIONS Moving swiftly to reverse years of financial decline, the new head of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans to cut costs by 10 percent, largely by reducing its staff through attrition, early retirement and layoffs, a company spokesman says. A1. NEW YORK CITY NEW LIMIT FOR SHELTERING FAMILIES New York City will soon refuse to shelter families who say they are homeless but who could continue to live with friends or family, or who abandon their own apartments because of crime in their neighborhoods, officials say. A1.

title: BETWEEN SPEECHES WITH Chief Judge Judith Smith Kaye; In the Matter of Prestigious Jobs, Red Shoes and Grandchildren
description: WHEN Judith Smith Kaye rose last Saturday to speak at the annual meeting of the American Bar Association -- kicking off a discussion of "Is the Law Male?" -- it was the fifth of 10 talks she would give at the convention, a feat surpassed only by the president and the president-elect of the bar group.

title: U.S. May Send Commandos To Hunt for Somali Warlord
description: The Administration is considering using commandos to search Mogadishu for Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, the Somali warlord who the United States believes was behind the killing of four American soldiers, United States officials said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CATERPILLAR INC., Peoria, Ill., said it had signed an agreement with Uralmash, a heavy-machinery producer in Moscow, to develop a new drilling rig and produce oil-drilling equipment.

title: View of German Upturn Is Met With Skepticism
description: In an apparent attempt to talk Germany out of its worst recession since World War II, Economics Minister Gunter Rexrodt said today that the economy's downward trend had stopped and that a mild recovery would begin in the second half of this year.

description: b-Included a gain of $ 3,391,000, or 82 cents a share, from cumulative effect for adopting new accounting standard for treatment of income taxes.

description: Moving swiftly to reverse years of financial decline, the new head of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans to cut costs by 10 percent, largely by reducing its staff through attrition, early retirement and layoffs, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: Court Backs Lesbian's Right To Adopt a Partner's Child
description: A family court judge has upheld a lesbian's right to become the adoptive parent of her partner's child, in an unusually detailed opinion addressing a practice that has been growing, largely out of public view, since the mid-1980's.

title: Review/Dance; From Taiwan, Energetic Ceremonies of Motion
description: The dance and music performed by the Formosa Aboriginal Dance Troupe of Taiwan on Sunday afternoon at the Fountain Plaza at Lincoln Center were ceremonies filled with repeated movements and sounds. But the performers, appearing as part of the center's Out of Doors festival, were one of the rare groups who managed to overcome the distractions of the setting. Car horns, conversations, excited children and the city's busy skyscape paled before the authority, simplicity and radiant humanity of the company, seen here in its American debut.

title: Productivity Of Workers Falls Sharply
description: After rising steadily for almost two years, the productivity of American workers dropped between January and June, the Labor Department said today in a report that could raise worries about layoffs or renewed inflationary pressures.

title: Saberhagen Belatedly Admits to Bleach Squirt
description: In a statement released by the Mets yesterday, Bret Saberhagen admitted responsibility for the July 27 bleach-spraying incident in the Shea Stadium clubhouse. The pitcher agreed to make amends for his actions and offered a formal apology both for his behavior that night and for his failure to acknowledge his role at an earlier date.

title: Rich Aren't Rushing to Avoid New Taxes (Yet)
description: The Dreyfus Corporation, one of the largest distributors of tax-free mutual funds, ran full page ads on Monday, the first business day after the Clinton tax bill passed, offering a toll-free telephone number to discuss shifting investments into tax-exempt funds. Only 50 people responded.

CHAIRMAN OF MIRAGE RAISES $21.1 MILLION IN STOCK SALE
description: Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman of Mirage Resorts Inc., has raised about $21.1 million by selling 450,000 shares of company stock last week at $47 a share, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Wynn plans to use some of the proceeds to build a new house with enhanced security, according to Daniel Lee, chief financial officer of Mirage. The stock sales leave Mr. Wynn with a 19.5 percent stake in Mirage. The stock dropped $2.25 yesterday, to $47.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Blockbuster Widens Talks With Agencies
